Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 06:41PM florencedonna wrote: Dear dcjoslin, After I finished my treatment, I had a strong drive to know the statistics on prognosis for my type of cancer.  I felt like I wanted to know the statistics I was going to decide didn't really apply to me!  Once I got the not so great news I didn't think about it much.  If you go fishing for prognosis info on the internet, beware of old data.  I recommend asking your oncologist.  Mine was comfortable giving info about prognosis but is not doom and gloom.  donna

Posts.Title: Did I over react? FIred a nurse yesterday.... AlaskaDeb snowyday

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 06:08AM florencedonna wrote: Naomi, your doctor's estimate of 80% over 10 years sounds too high to me.  My oncologist estimated 25% of recurrence for me over my lifetime; he also said that a large percentage of recurrences occur in the first two years after diagnosis.  I may have a better prognosis because I am Her + and had herceptin. My concern has been about metastases, not about local recurrence in the scar or a new primary breast cancer.  My onc estimates a 10% lifetime risk of a brand new breast cancer. If you want to talk to your oncologist again I would specifically ask him ... What does he mean by 80% chance of recurrence, does he mean 80% chance of metastases or 80 % chance of metastases, local recurrence or a new primary? You are 3 years out from diagnosis (yah!!!), How does the passage of time without metastasis affect your odds of developing metastasis? I assume you are able to tolerate whatever treatment was recommended; how does completing treatment affect the estimate? (prior to the injections for low blood counts and the drugs for nausea, a huge percentage of people could not complete the recommended chemo plan) I would suggest talking to him because I think it is likely that you will hear information that is more hopeful.  If you do decide to have this talk, give the onc notice you want to talk about this so he is  prepared and you may want to bring someone with you. Some food for thought:  I am in the health care field.  Now that I am attuned to breast cancer, I ask women much more about their breast cancer than I did in the past.  I am upset frequently to find women who don't know much about their breast cancer and are not taking their tamoxifen.  I assume the sisters on bc.org will have a better prognosis because they are informed about the disease.  I am sure being on this site decreases you lifetime risk by 5% I wonder how treatment will change when circulating tumor cell tests are more common.  will we change treatments when there is an increase in tumor cells circulating in the blood even before they settle in to grow in the bone or liver?  If you develop mets five years from now, we'll have more treatments than we do now.    The glass is 3/4's full!  donna
Posts.Title: 80 % chance of it coming back!!! Naomi browneyes2323

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 10:02AM florencedonna wrote: Tracy, That is just terrible.  The nurse is supposed to be comfort to you, not make you feel worse.  Not only did she start off in a negative way but she didn't respect your signals that you did not want to hear it.  It sounds like she wanted to say it whether you wanted to hear it or not and that is not respectful of your rights.  It is especially egregious since you are complying with a treatment that is making you feel wretched.  Are you on a ton of steroids with the taxol? (dexamethasone, prednisone) steroids play havoc with your mood and cause your stomach to produce extra acid.  Some of the OTC meds come in higher strengths as a prescription.  Carafate is an old medication that coats the stomach/esophagus.  Maybe the acid has made your esophagus a little raw so the reflux hurts even more. Here's sending you comfort.  donna
Posts.Title: taxol is horrid Tracy1964 AusAla

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2008 04:16AM florencedonna wrote: Crystal-- if the form isn't clear what you do to get excused, call your pcp's office and ask the staff.  They must do this all the time.  I write these letters so often for my patients that I have a form letter.  In Massachusetts, the doctor's letter has to state why the illness interferes with performing as a juror, I always state "poor concentration".  In Massachusetts, a physician can get someone permanently excused from jury duty, if you want, ask your pcp if you can be permanently excused.  donna
Posts.Title: Jury Duty? Are they kidding me?! ccarter48818 Skyrat

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2009 08:35PM florencedonna wrote: I wondered if my breast cancer was related to radiation exposure from a cardiac catheterization I had at age 14.  I remember watching the fluoroscopy image with fascination as they did the procedure.  I also felt bad about going 5 years without a mammogram from age 38 to 43.  Then my sister was diagnosed a year after I was, my sister who had no radiation exposure, whose breast cancer was diagnosed 9 months after a negative mammogram, who had her first child before 30. My sister and I developing cancer, a year apart, both at age 43, made me realize how complex breast cancer formation is.  I am BRCA 1,2  negative. Do we have an unknown genetic propensity, were we exposed to a carcinogen as a child, who knows? US News and world report (May 30, 2008) : one chest CT is 10 millisieverts of radiation, one chest X Ray, 0.02 millisieverts of radiation  Donna
Posts.Title: I feel I am high risk due to radiation exposure as teen kibbles AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2008 05:24PM florencedonna wrote: Elena, I worked full time during my chemo and radiation; I'm a psychiatrist which is not physically draining but can be emotionally draining. My oncologist told me not to see patients who were febrile who were on antibiotics for less than 24  hours.  My oncologists gave me Emenda and Zofran for nausea; I didn't vomit once and I got neulasta before my counts dropped to a dangerous level. My fatigue hit in the evening; I was my normal self during the day but went to bed at 8:30 pm instead of 11:00. I was able to work full time because my husband managed the house and my job was very flexible.  I hope you can stick with medical school.  I feel having cancer has broadened my understanding of what it means to be a patient.  I just saw an acquaintance, an OB with chemo hair and an internist I know took time off for treatment of leukemia and is back full time. Best wishes, donna
Posts.Title: anyone worked or gone to school during treatment elsko kagaines

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 10:08PM - edited Apr 9, 2008 10:10PM by florencedonna luckywife, do you have all the structural things in place to make it easier to do these transfers, ie a raised toilet seat, bars by the toilet that are firmly attached to the wall, a trapeze over the bed?  If you don't maybe the physical therapy dept or the social worker at the hospital can give some advice.  Maybe a medical supply store might have some equipment.  would a walker help for those short distances from chair to toilet and back to chair.  do you wear footie socks with non skid strips on them? I don't know much about your situation so I may be way off base but I so strongly wish for you to get out of bed as much as possible and not to be afraid of falling when going to the bathroom that I threw out what I could think of. good luck, donna

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 12:36PM florencedonna wrote: I think atypical lymphocytes would be normal as your bone marrow struggles to put out cells while being attacked by chemo. Can you get neulasta to boost your wbc so your chemo isn't delayed? I think leukemia caused by AC is a complication that occurs ?years after you complete chemo.  low counts for erythrocytes, hemoglobin and hematocrit are all various tests that reflect anemia from decreased production of red blood cells, normal with chemo.  low platelet volume is also normal with chemo.  I got very anxious when I picked up my own lab studies to find mild elevation of liver function tests while getting chemo.  I spent the weekend convinced I had liver mets to find out that a mild increase is normal with chemo. I am now three years out from diagnosis! Here's wishing you easy treatments and good results.  donna

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2009 11:15AM florencedonna wrote: My brother in law had recurrent vocal cord polyps- probably from too much stomach acid refluxing up and hitting the vocal cords.  I think polyps and nodules on the vocal cords are actually pretty common.  I think when mets affect the vocal cords it is usually from pressure in the mediastinum on the left recurrent laryngeal nerve causing paralysis of the left vocal cord and not mets on the actual vocal cords.  Here's hoping the surgery took care of the problem.  donna
